title: I received a notice of levy under writ of execution --money judgement from a credit card debt years ago. What do I do?
question: My assets car and rent are in my husbands name and I'm on his account can that be seized? What is better calling tge attorney or filing a claim of exemption... Collectively we live pay check to pay check
answers:
If you're living check to check, owe a substantial amount and have little in the way of assets, now would be a good time to get a free consultation with a bankruptcy lawyer. You'll find a lot of goods ones here on Avvo.

Good luck!

Rob

Assuming all of your present assets are exempt, your future income, including your husband's income, is subject to a wage garnishment of up to 25%. Is this debt large enough to justify you filing bankruptcy? Do you have other old, bad debt that justifys the filing of a bankruptcy? A good local bankruptcy lawyer can advise you on that.

The fact that you live pay check to pay check shows how hard you are struggling, but it does not protect you from having to pay a judgment. If you don't voluntarily pay a dbt, and don't discharge the debt in bankruptcy, the law allows a judgment creditor to use a levy to force repayment.
This needs to be under debt settlement.

Anything you legally own is subject to the levy. You also have state law exemptions that apply to prevent certain things in certain dollar amounts from being taken from you. The levy is a process and you need to get involved to assert your rights. They may freeze your bank account and ask for your car. Then it's up to you to show why they should not get to do that. The only alternative is to negotiate some payment terms (always in writing) or file bankruptcy to protect yourself.
You need to talk to your own lawyer for legal advise and an assessment of your legal rights and obligations. If you qualify, you should file a Claim of Exemption immediately.
